fr:ul.fr:li: After a bit more digging, the main culprit here is the countable subadditivity condition of measure.

In a discrete probability space, the entire space is at most countable. Therefore, if each individual event has zero probability then the countable union i.e. the whole space will have zero probability.
In measure theoretic probability, we are able to accumulate non-zero probability mass from an uncountable union of zero measure events.
I guess the canonical example of this is that each point on a line has length 0, but the line itself (an uncountable union of points) has non-zero length.
In the dyadic intervals example, each event of an arbitrary discrete probability space can be identified with a point on the line of probability zero.

1663kak-000Nkak-000N.xmlProblem 1.1 BillingsleySolution20241117
A discrete probability space cannot contain an infinite sequence of independent events A_1, A_2, \ldots each with probability 1/2. To see this, denote the event space as \mathcal {X}. Note that P(A_1 \cap A_2) + P(A_1 \cap A_2^c) + P(A_1^c \cap A_2) + P(A_1^c \cap A_2^c) = 1 Therefore, every x \in \mathcal {X} must be in one of those four events and have probability at most 1/4. Similarly, we can construct n disjoint sets in the same manner and bound \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) by 1/n. Taking n \to \infty , we have that \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) = 0. Since \mathcal {X} is a discrete probability space, we must have that \sum _{x \in \mathcal {X}} \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) = 1 However, we have just shown that for each x \in \mathcal {X}, \mathbb {P}(\{x\}) = 0. Thus, we have reached a contradiction.
I think my main takeaway from this is that infinite sequences break discrete probability because each discrete event will have probability zero. This is not actually a problem because in an infinite sequence the occurence of any such sequence "feasibly" has zero probability. However, we still want to reason about probabilistic things like the convergence of the average of the sequence. Since discrete probability is broken, we cannot even use it for these things. This is why we need to use measure theory to allow for zero probability sequences, but still provide information about these more "general" events. Who knows if this intuition is right though?

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
We now want to show that the extension we developed in the previous section is actually unique. The first question we have is what do we mean by unique? To answer this, we need to remember what we have done so far.
We have a Probability Measure P, defined on an algebra \mathscr {F}_0.
We then extended P to \sigma (\mathscr {F}_0) via P^*, so that for every A \in \mathscr {F}_0 we have P(A) = P^*(A) and P^* is defined on all of \sigma (\mathscr {F}_0) From this, our only restriction is that P^*(A) = P(A) for A \in \mathscr {F}_0. Therefore, uniqueness here means that if P^*(A) = Q(A) for some Q and every A \in \mathscr {F}_0. Then P^*(A) = Q(A) for every A \in \sigma (\mathscr {F}_0).
A class \mathcal {P} of subsets of \Omega is a \pi -system if it is closed under the formation of finite intersections: A,B\in \mathcal {P} \implies A\cap B\in \mathcal {P}.

The union of any two disjoint two point sets will be \Omega . However, a non-disjoint union of two disjoint sets can result in a three point set, which is not in \mathscr {L}. These non-disjoint unions would be covered in a \sigma -field.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: To remedy this disconnect, we have the following lemma:
A class that is both a \pi -system and a \lambda -system is a \sigma -field.
In our example, we could take the intersection of say \{x_1, x_2\} and \{x_2, x_3\} to get \{x_2\}. We could then take a disjoint union of \{x_1, x_3\} and \{x_2\} to get \{x_1, x_2, x_3\}.
If \mathscr {P} is a \pi -system and \mathscr {L} is a \lambda -system, then \mathscr {P}\subset \mathscr {L} implies \sigma (\mathscr {P})\subset \mathscr {L}.
Now we will see how this allows us to prove our desired result i.e. the uniqueness of our extension of a probability on an algebra to the kak-0000 via the outer measure.

Suppose that P_{1} and P_{2} are probability measures on \sigma (\mathscr {P}), where \mathscr {P} is a \pi -system. If P_{1} and P_{2} agree on \mathscr {P}, then they agree on \sigma (\mathscr {P}).

fr:tree.fr:mainmatter: Take \mathscr {L} to be the class of sets such that A \in \mathscr {L} \implies P_1(A) = P_2(A). Since \mathscr {P} is a \pi -system, from Theorem 9, it is sufficient to show that \mathscr {L} is a \lambda -system. Since \Omega \in \mathscr {P}, \Omega \in \mathscr {L}. If A \in \mathscr {L}, then P_1(A^c) = 1 - P_1(A) = 1 - P_2(A) = P_2(A^c). Therefore, A^c \in \mathscr {L}. From Theorem 9, \sigma (\mathscr {P}) \subset \mathscr {L} and P_1 and P_2 agree on all of \sigma (\mathscr {P}).

Namely, countable additivity is really a condition on countable disjoint unions, meaning that the \sigma -field induced by a Probability Measure does not make full use of the generality allowed under arbitrary countable unions because it must satisfy countable additivity.
For completeness and future use, we introduce here the notion of monotone classes and Halmo's useful theorem.
If \mathscr {F}_{0} is a field and \mathscr {A} is a monotone class, then \mathscr {F}_{0}\subset \mathscr {A} implies \sigma (\mathscr {F}_{0})\subset \mathscr {A}.
Also for completeness, we introduce completeness lol.
A probability measure (\Omega , \mathcal {F}, P) is complete if for A \subset B if P(B) = 0 then P(A) = 0.
You might be wondering when this is not the case because we have subadditivity. However, it is not the case that P(A) > 0 but instead that A is not measurable. As an example,

If we consider [0,1], then we can partition [0, 1] into equivalent classes as x \sim y if x - y = r for some r \in \mathbb {Q} \cap [0, 1]. Denote each of these as V_{r}. By the Axiom of Choice, we can choose one representative from each V_r. We call the set of these representatives V. Therefore, we can write [0, 1] as a countable union via [0,1] = \bigcup _{r \in \mathbb {Q}} V + r. For the Lebesgue measure \lambda , each \lambda (V + r) = \lambda (V). Since each V + r is disjoint, we have \lambda \left (\bigcup _{r \in \mathbb {Q}} V + r\right ) = \sum _{r \in \mathbb {Q}} \lambda (V) If \lambda (V) = 0, then \lambda ([0,1]) \leq \lambda (V) = 0 which is a contradiction. Otherwise \lambda ([0,1]) = \sum _{r \in \mathbb {Q}} k = \infty for some k \in \mathbb {R}. Thus, V is not Lebesgue measurable.

Let P be a probability measure on a field \mathscr {F}_{0} and for every subset A of \Omega define P^{\star }(A) by (3.1). Denote also by P the extension of P to \mathscr {F}=\sigma (\mathscr {F}_{0}).
Show that A is P^*-measurable if and only if P^*(A) = P_*(A).

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: First suppose that P^*(A) = P_*(A). Let E \subset \Omega . We must show that P^*(E \cap A) + P^*(E \cap A^c) = P^*(E) From part (1) and our hypothesis, \exists \overline {A}, \underline {A} \in \mathscr {F} such that \underline {A} \subset A \subset \overline {A} and P(\overline {A}) = P^*(A) = P_*(A) = P(\underline {A}). Additionally, \exists B \in \mathscr {F} such that E \subset B and P^*(E) = P(B). Then we have that P^*(E \cap A) \leq P^*(B \cap \overline {A}) = P(B \cap \overline {A}) and P^*(B \cap A) \leq P^*(B \cap \underline {A}^c) = P(B \cap \underline {A}^c) Thus, P^*(E \cap A) + P^*(E \cap A^c) \leq P(B \cap \underline {A}^c) + P(B \cap \overline {A}) = P^*(E) as desired.

Let X_1, \ldots , X_n be Simple Random Variable's
The \sigma -field \sigma (X_1, \ldots , X_n) consists of the sets \left [(X_1, \ldots , X_n) \in H\right ] = \left [\omega \mid (X_1(\omega ), \ldots , X_n(\omega )) \in H\right ] for H \subset \mathbb {R}^n.
A simple random variable Y is measurable \sigma (X_1, \ldots , X_n) if and only if Y = f(X_1, \ldots , X_n) for some f: \mathbb {R}^n \to \mathbb {R}.

The \sigma -field generated by a Simple Random Variable is the smallest \sigma -field such that the Simple Random Variable is measurable. For a sequence of Simple Random Variable's, the \sigma -field generated by them is the smallest \sigma -field, such that each of the Simple Random Variable's is measurable.

fr:mainmatter.fr:p: A Simple Random Variable of the form X = \sum _{i} x_i I_{A_i} is assigned expected value as \mathbb {E}[X] = \mathbb {E}\left [\sum _i x_i I_{A_i} \right ] = \sum _i x_i P(A_i) More generally, if f(X) = \sum _i f(x_i) I_{A_i} then \mathbb {E}\left [f(X)\right ] = \sum _i f(x_i) P(A_i) = \sum _x f(x) P[X = x] A useful identity is as follows: \mathbb {E}[X] = \int _0^{\infty } P[X \geq x] \mathrm {d}x
We define the kth moment of X as \mathbb {E}[X^k] = \sum _y y P[X^k = y]
If \exists K such that X_n(\omega ) \leq K for every \omega and n then the X_n are uniformly bounded.
If \{X_n\} is uniformly bounded, and if X = \lim _n X_n with probability 1, then \mathbb {E}[X] = \lim _n \mathbb {E}[X]
If \phi is a convex function on the range of X then \phi (\mathbb {E}[X]) \leq \mathbb {E}[\phi (X)]

Suppose that \frac {1}{p} + \frac {1}{q} = 1, \quad p > 1,\ q > 1 Then Holder's inequality is \mathbb {E}[XY] \leq \left (\mathbb {E}[|X|^p]\right )^{1/p} \cdot \left (\mathbb {E}[|Y|^q]\right )^{1/q}
